qas.question: At what rate have glaciers travelled during surges?
What is the term for a gradual increase in a glaciers speed?
What is caused by underground water?
What does accumulaion of rock under the glacier cause?

context: A few glaciers have <a0_0>periods of very rapid advancement<a0_0/> called <b3_0>surges<b3_0/>. These glaciers exhibit normal movement until suddenly they accelerate, then return to their previous state. During these <b4_0><b5_0>surges<b5_0/><b4_0/>, the glacier may reach velocities far greater than normal speed. These surges may be caused by <a1_0>failure of the underlying bedrock<a1_0/>, the pooling of meltwater at the base of the glacier — perhaps delivered from a supraglacial lake — or the simple accumulation of mass beyond a critical "tipping point". Temporary rates up to <a2_0>90 m (300 ft) per day<a2_0/> have occurred when increased temperature or overlying pressure caused bottom ice to melt and water to accumulate beneath a glacier.
